discussion.content:
Maybe: B. The systems administrator did not perform a full system scan ?
A credentialed scan will give you all the information you would get from a non-credentialed scam, and then some.

Selected Answer: B
The question specifies that they only scanned the intranet, leading me to believe the systems administrator did not perform a full system scan. The AIO book explains the different security zones on page 191, so if they only scanned the org's intranet, they missed the org's extranet which has public visibility via the DMZZ.

"Full System" Scan usually means scanning of an entire device rather than a entire network. 
So possibly the option is D
I hate CompTIA for questions such as these.

I'm thinking B -- because if the administrator performed a credentialed scan they would have everything they need. Credentialed scans are recommended to conduct. Credentialed scans are more detailed. So I'm confused on this answer and why it would be C

Maybe: D. The vulnerability database was not updated ?
B and D seem about equally likely to me.

comments.content: I don't think it's D because even if the vulnerability database WAS updated, they still only scanned the intranet. The attack could have came through the org's extranet which has public visibility via the DMZ.

choices.D: The vulnerability database was not updated
choices.A: There was a false positive since the network was fully patched
choices.B: The systems administrator did not perform a full system scan
choices.C: The systems administrator performed a credentialed scan

questions.question_text: A systems administrator recently conducted a vulnerability scan of the intranet. Subsequently, the organization was successfully attacked by an adversary. Which of the following is the MOST likely explanation for why the organization's network was compromised?

discussion.content:
BASED ON OUTPUT THE CERTIFICATE WAS GENERATED TO BE USED FOR 2 THINGS : CERTIFICATE SIGN. CRL SIGN. ( NO vpn IS MENTIONED)

What does Key Usage Critical mean?
An extended key is either critical or non-critical. If the extension is critical, the certificate must be used only for the indicated purpose or purposes.

comments.content: youre right, answer can be found in the key usage part

Thank you for that complete explanation. So many comments of the form "It's C" or "given answer is correct." These are the type of explanations that actually teach us something and help us understand.

discussion.content:
Maybe: C. The user's certificate was not created for VPN use ?
I am not seeing any evidence of compromise

choices.D: The user's certificate was created using insecure encryption algorithms
choices.A: The user's certificate is not signed by the VPN service provider
choices.B: The user's certificate has been compromised and should be revoked
choices.C: The user's certificate was not created for VPN use

discussion.content:
Maybe for Step 1: 
Permit TCP from 10.100.2.0/24 to 172.16.0.20/24 port 1433 ?
The given answer shows "172.16.0.20/32" instead of 172.16.0.20/24.
Also, I know the port for RDP is 3389. But the port for MS-SQL is 1433. Would connect to the DB server at 3389, or 1433?
In the ACLs IP means TCP + UDP + ICMP + GRE etc.
Why do we use Permit TCP instead of Permit UDP on step 2? What is the difference between Permit IP/TCP/UDP? Thanks

comments.content:
Web servers must use stateful connections to databases when they query them.
TCP = Layer 4, Stateful connection, monitors for dropped packets, ensures delivery
UDP = Layer 4, Stateless connection, delivery not guaranteed, used for services like VOIP
IP = Layer 3 transport protocol, typically for network management (think PING commands) but can be used with applications. While TCP and UDP both run over IP, IP is an independent protocol. 
Typically if we want to restrict the TYPE OF SERVICE or PORT RANGE between two nodes, we would need to specify TCP/UDP. If we want to allow ALL Protocols and Ports to run between two nodes, we would use permit IP (although you are able to filter ports with a permit IP command). 
Hope that helps!

questions.question_text: An insurance company has two million customers and is researching the top transactions on its customer portal. It identifies that the top transaction is currently password reset. Due to users not remembering their secret questions, a large number of calls are consequently routed to the contact center for manual password resets. The business wants to develop a mobile application to improve customer engagement in the future, continue with a single factor of authentication, minimize management overhead of the solution, remove passwords, and eliminate to the contact center. Which of the following techniques would BEST meet the requirements? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
A C
are solution that actually exist in the wild.

A and D.
A - https://www.okta.com/blog/2020/09/magic-links/
D - we are using google,meta, other socmed to login to mobile application for a while now

2million users, not possible to issue certificate due sheer number of users.
OTP is part of 2FA.
I am curious; for those saying C, is that not part of a 2FA? the question clearly states that the company wants to continue with a "single factor authentication". I will go with A & D

comments.content: Then emailing reset link can be also considered as 2FA .. isnt it ?

discussion.content: I understand C, but why NOT E?

comments.content: Installing client certs on your computer is a lot like accepting cookies--security conscious people won't want to install a dozen certs on their machines. Plus the certs would have to be tied to the device, that means you'll need one for your phone and one for each computer or other mobile device. Also, what's the expiration date on these certs? How do you prevent access if a cert is stolen and an ID spoofed? Are you issuing a new cert every week? Every month? A&C are single-use ephemeral access solutions that use customer-provided contact information to ensure account security. It's neither practical nor plausible to run a certificate tree and start issuing out a million certs to a million customers.

discussion.content:
Agree with A & C being the answer.

https://www.loginradius.com/blog/start-with-identity/2020/10/loginradius-launches-passwordless-login-with-magic-link-or-otp/

choices.B: Customer ID sent via push notification
choices.E: Certificate sent to be installed on a device
choices.C: SMS with OTP sent to a mobile number
choices.A: Magic link sent to an email address

choices.D: Capture the risk in a prioritized register that is shared routinely with the CEO
choices.C: Modify policies and standards to discourage future changes that increase risk
choices.B: Pilot new mitigations that cost less than the total amount saved by the change
choices.A: Present the detailed risk resulting from the change to the company's board of directors

discussion.content:
Maybe: A. Present the detailed risk resulting from the change to the company's board of directors ?
The CEO should run such ideas by the board. I am not sure what is meant by "capture the risk in a prioritized register." And why would the CEO want put to something where it will be shared by the CEO? He/she is the CEO.

comments.content: Option A is presenting the risk resulting from the change, so the change has already happened in this option. The questions asks for a COA to MANAGE the risk. I guess I took this as something more active and evolving, which makes me think D is correct. I'm not sure what a "prioritized register" is, something that lists the risks, ranked by priority. I feel like there is something that's called, but can't remember what it's official name is.
My first thought was an SRTM.

questions.question_text: The Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of a company has considered implementing a cost-saving measure that might result in new risk to the company. When deciding whether to implement this measure, which of the following would be the BEST course of action to manage the organization's risk?
